a.g: The command of Allah is coming, so be not impatient for it. Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him.
He sends down the angels, with the inspiration of His command, upon whom He wills of His servants, [telling them], "Warn that there is no deity except Me; so fear Me."
He created the heavens and earth in truth. High is He above what they associate with Him.
He created man from a sperm-drop; then at once, he is a clear adversary.
And the grazing livestock He has created for you; in them is warmth and [numerous] benefits, and from them you eat.
And for you in them is [the enjoyment of] beauty when you bring them in [for the evening] and when you send them out [to pasture].
And they carry your loads to a land you could not have reached except with difficulty to yourselves. Indeed, your Lord is Kind and Merciful.
And [He created] the horses, mules and donkeys for you to ride and [as] adornment. And He creates that which you do not know.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k09
Indeed, know that everything in existence besides God, the Exalted, is the action [fi'l] and creation [khalq] of God. And every atom of the atoms—be it substance, accident, attribute, or that which is described—contains wonders and marvels through which the wisdom [hikma], power [qudra], majesty [jalal], and greatness ['azama] of God are made manifest. Enumerating that is not possible, for if the sea were ink for that, the sea would be exhausted before a tenth of its tenth is exhausted. Yet, we point to a summary of it so that it may serve as an example for what lies beyond it. So We say: The created existents are divided into that whose origin we do not know, so we cannot contemplate it—and how many existents do we not know, as God, the Exalted, said: **"And He creates what you do not know"** [16:8]. Glory to Him Who created all pairs from what the earth grows, from themselves, and from what they do not know [36:36]. And He said: **"And We will develop you into that which you do not know"** [56:61]. And into that whose origin and totality we know, but whose details we do not know, so we can contemplate its details. And it is divided into what we perceive with the sense of sight, and into what we do not perceive with sight. As for what we do not perceive with sight, such as the angels, the jinn, the devils, the Throne ['arsh], the Footstool [kursi], and other than that, the scope for thought [fikr] in these things is narrow and obscure, so let us turn to what is closer to comprehension, which is that which is perceived by the sense of sight. And that is the seven heavens and the earth and what is between them. The heavens are observed with their stars, sun, moon, their movement and rotation in their rising and setting. The earth is observed with what it contains of its mountains, minerals, rivers, seas, animals, and plants. And what is between the heaven and the earth—which is the atmosphere—is perceived with its clouds, rains, snows, thunder, lightning, thunderbolts, shooting stars, and stormy winds. These are the observable genera of the heavens, the earth, and what is between them. And every genus of them divides into species, and every species divides into categories, and every category branches into varieties. And there is no end to that branching and division in the differences of its attributes, its forms, and its apparent and hidden meanings. And all of that is a field for contemplation [fikr]. Not a single atom in the heavens and the earth moves—be it inanimate, plant, animal, celestial sphere, or star—except that God, the Exalted, is its mover. And in its movement is one wisdom [hikma], or two, or ten, or a thousand wisdoms. All of that bears witness [shahid] for God, the Exalted, to Oneness [wahdaniyya] and points to His majesty [jalal] and grandeur [kibriya']. And these are the signs [ayat] pointing to Him. And the Qur'an has come urging contemplation [tafakkur] on these signs, as God, the Exalted, said: **"Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding"** [3:190]. And as He, the Exalted, said: **"And among His signs..."** from the beginning of the Qur'an to its end. So let Us mention the manner of contemplation on some of the signs. Among His signs is the human [insan], created from a sperm-drop. And the closest thing to you is your own self [nafs]. And within you are marvels pointing to the greatness of God, the Exalted, which lifetimes would be spent in standing before a tenth of its tenth, while you are heedless [ghafil] of it. So O you who are heedless of your own self and ignorant of it, how do you aspire to know other than yourself? And God, the Exalted, has commanded you to reflect [tadabbur] upon your self in His Mighty Book, saying: **"And in yourselves. Then will you not see?"** [51:21]. And He reminded that you...

a.g: And upon Allah is the direction of the [right] way, and among the various paths are those deviating. And if He willed, He could have guided you all.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k08
Indeed, He intended by it knowledge [al-'ilm]. And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "And upon Allah is the direction of the path [qasd al-sabil]."

a.g: It is He who sends down rain from the sky; from it is drink and from it is foliage in which you pasture [animals].
He causes to grow for you thereby the crops, olives, palm trees, grapevines, and from all the fruits. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who give thought.
And He has subjected for you the night and day and the sun and moon, and the stars are subjected by His command. Indeed in that are signs for a people who reason.
And [He has subjected] whatever He multiplied for you on the earth of varying colors. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who remember.

And it is He who subjected the sea for you to eat from it tender meat and to extract from it ornaments which you wear. And you see the ships plowing through it, and [He subjected it] that you may seek of His bounty; and perhaps you will be grateful.
And He has cast into the earth firmly set mountains, lest it shift with you, and [made] rivers and roads, that you may be guided,
And landmarks. And by the stars they are [also] guided.
Then is He who creates like one who does not create? So will you not be reminded?
And if you should count the favors of Allah, you could not enumerate them. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
And Allah knows what you conceal and what you declare.
And those they invoke other than Allah create nothing, and they [themselves] are created.
They are, [in fact], dead, not alive, and they do not perceive when they will be resurrected.
Your god is one God. But those who do not believe in the Hereafter - their hearts are disapproving, and they are arrogant.
Assuredly, Allah knows what they conceal and what they declare. Indeed, He does not like the arrogant.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, He [Allah] does not love the arrogant [al-mustakbireen]. And the censure of arrogance [al-kibr] in the Qur'an is abundant. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "He will not enter Paradise, he in whose heart [qalb] is the weight of a mustard seed of arrogance [kibr]; and he will not enter the Fire, he in whose heart [qalb] is the weight of a mustard seed of faith [iman]." And Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Allah the Exalted says: 'Grandeur [al-kibriya'] is My cloak, and majesty [al-'azamah] is My garment. So whoever contends with Me for one of them, I will cast him into Hellfire, and I will not care.'"

So whoever contends with Me for one of them, I will cast him into Hellfire, and I will not care.'"

a.g: And when it is said to them, "What has your Lord sent down?" They say, "Legends of the former peoples,"
That they may bear their own burdens in full on the Day of Resurrection and some of the burdens of those whom they misguide without knowledge. Unquestionably, evil is that which they bear.

Those before them had already plotted, but Allah came at their building from the foundations, so the roof fell upon them from above them, and the punishment came to them from where they did not perceive.

Then on the Day of Resurrection He will disgrace them and say, "Where are My 'partners' for whom you used to oppose [the believers]?" Those who were given knowledge will say, "Indeed disgrace, this Day, and evil are upon the disbelievers" -
The ones whom the angels take in death [while] wronging themselves, and [who] then offer submission, [saying], "We were not doing any evil." But, yes! Indeed, Allah is Knowing of what you used to do.
So enter the gates of Hell to abide eternally therein, and how wretched is the residence of the arrogant.

And it will be said to those who feared Allah, "What did your Lord send down?" They will say, "[That which is] good." For those who do good in this world is good; and the home of the Hereafter is better. And how excellent is the home of the righteous -
Gardens of perpetual residence, which they will enter, beneath which rivers flow. They will have therein whatever they wish. Thus does Allah reward the righteous -
The ones whom the angels take in death, [being] good and pure; [the angels] will say, "Peace be upon you. Enter Paradise for what you used to do."

Do the disbelievers await [anything] except that the angels should come to them or there comes the command of your Lord? Thus did those do before them. And Allah wronged them not, but they had been wronging themselves.
So they were struck by the evil consequences of what they did and were enveloped by what they used to ridicule.

And those who associate others with Allah say, "If Allah had willed, we would not have worshipped anything other than Him, neither we nor our fathers, nor would we have forbidden anything through other than Him." Thus did those do before them. So is there upon the messengers except [the duty of] clear notification?

And We certainly sent into every nation a messenger, [saying], "Worship Allah and avoid Taghut." And among them were those whom Allah guided, and among them were those upon whom error was [deservedly] decreed. So proceed through the earth and observe how was the end of the deniers.
[Even] if you should strive for their guidance, [O Muhammad], indeed, Allah does not guide those He sends astray, and they will have no helpers.
And they swear by Allah their strongest oaths [that] Allah will not resurrect one who dies. But yes - [it is] a true promise [binding] upon Him, but most of the people do not know.
[It is] so He will make clear to them [the truth of] that wherein they differ and so those who have disbelieved may know that they were liars.
Indeed, Our word to a thing when We intend it is but that We say to it, "Be," and it is.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 2
Indeed, from this category in its allusion to absolute power [al-iqtidar] is His saying, the Most High: "Indeed, Our command [qawluna] to a thing, when We will it, is that We say to it, 'Be,' and it is." {Surah An-Nahl: 40}. For its outward meaning [zahiruhu] is impossible, for His saying 'Be'—if it is an address [khitab] to the thing before its existence—then it is absurd, since the non-existent [al-ma'dum] does not comprehend the address until it is given form. And if it is after existence, then it is in no need of being brought into being [al-takwin]. However, since this allusion [al-kinaya] is more impactful upon the souls [al-nufus] in conveying the ultimate degree of power [ghayat al-iqtidar], He turned to it.

a.g: And those who emigrated for [the cause of] Allah after they had been wronged - We will surely settle them in this world in a good place; but the reward of the Hereafter is greater, if only they could know.
[They are] those who endured patiently and upon their Lord relied.
And We sent not before you except men to whom We revealed [Our message]. So ask the people of the message if you do not know.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, I intended by it knowledge [al-'ilm], and the Most High said: "So ask the people of the Remembrance [ahl al-dhikr] if you do not know." And the Most High said: "Indeed, upon Us is the guidance [al-huda]." And He said: "Then indeed, upon Us is its clarification." And He said: "And upon Allah is the direction of the path [qasd al-sabil]."

a.g: [We sent them] with clear proofs and written ordinances. And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them and that they might give thought.
Then, do those who have planned evil deeds feel secure that Allah will not cause the earth to swallow them or that the punishment will not come upon them from where they do not perceive?
Or that He would not seize them during their [usual] activity, and they could not cause failure?
Or that He would not seize them gradually [in a state of dread]? But indeed, your Lord is Kind and Merciful.
Have they not considered what things Allah has created? Their shadows incline to the right and to the left, prostrating to Allah, while they are humble.
And to Allah prostrates whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth of creatures, and the angels [as well], and they are not arrogant.
They fear their Lord above them, and they do what they are commanded.
And Allah has said, "Do not take for yourselves two deities. He is but one God, so fear only Me."
And to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth, and to Him is [due] worship constantly. Then is it other than Allah that you fear?
And whatever you have of favor - it is from Allah. Then when adversity touches you, to Him you cry for help.
Then when He removes the adversity from you, at once a party of you associates others with their Lord
So they will deny what We have given them. Then enjoy yourselves, for you are going to know.
And they assign to what they do not know a portion of that which We have provided them. By Allah, you will surely be questioned about what you used to invent.
And they attribute to Allah daughters - exalted is He - and for them is what they desire.
And when one of them is informed of [the birth of] a female, his face becomes dark, and he suppresses grief.
He hides himself from the people because of the ill of which he has been informed. Should he keep it in humiliation or bury it in the ground? Unquestionably, evil is what they decide.
For those who do not believe in the Hereafter is the description of evil; and for Allah is the highest attribute. And He is Exalted in Might, the Wise.

And if Allah were to impose blame on the people for their wrongdoing, He would not have left upon the earth any creature, but He defers them for a specified term. And when their term has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it].

And they attribute to Allah that which they dislike, and their tongues assert the lie that they will have the best [from Him]. Assuredly, they will have the Fire, and they will be [therein] neglected.

By Allah, We did certainly send [messengers] to nations before you, but Satan made their deeds attractive to them. And he is the disbelievers' ally today [as well], and they will have a painful punishment.
And We have not revealed to you the Book, [O Muhammad], except for you to make clear to them that wherein they have differed and as guidance and mercy for a people who believe.
And Allah has sent down rain from the sky and given life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who listen.
And indeed, for you in grazing livestock is a lesson. We give you drink from what is in their bellies - between excretion and blood - pure milk, palatable to drinkers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k07 old
Know the reality of sincerity [ikhlas]. Indeed, every thing that can be conceived of as being mixed with something else, when it becomes pure from its mixture and is free from it, is called pure [khalis]. And the action that is purified and made pure is called sincerity [ikhlas]. Allah the Exalted said: "From between what is in the intestines and blood, pure milk [labanan khalisan], palatable for the drinkers." (16:66). The purity [khulus] of the milk is that there is no mixture in it of blood or what is in the intestines, nor of anything that can possibly mix with it. And sincerity [ikhlas] is the opposite of association [shirk]. So whoever is not sincere [mukhlis] is an associator [mushrik], except that association [shirk] has degrees. Sincerity [ikhlas] in divine oneness [tawhid] is the opposite of association [tashrik] in divinity [uluhiyyah]. And association [shirk] is of two kinds: hidden [khafi] and manifest [jali]. And likewise, sincerity [ikhlas]. And sincerity [ikhlas] and its opposite both come upon the heart [qalb]. Its place is the heart [qalb]. And this only occurs in intentions [qasd] and aims [niyyat].

a.g: And from the fruits of the palm trees and grapevines you take intoxicant and good provision. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who reason.
And your Lord inspired to the bee, "Take for yourself among the mountains, houses, and among the trees and [in] that which they construct.

Then eat from all the fruits and follow the ways of your Lord laid down [for you]." There emerges from their bellies a drink, varying in colors, in which there is healing for people. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who give thought.

And Allah created you; then He will take you in death. And among you is he who is reversed to the most decrepit [old] age so that he will not know, after [having had] knowledge, a thing. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Competent.

And Allah has favored some of you over others in provision. But those who were favored would not hand over their provision to those whom their right hands possess so they would be equal to them therein. Then is it the favor of Allah they reject?

And Allah has made for you from yourselves mates and has made for you from your mates sons and grandchildren and has provided for you from the good things. Then in falsehood do they believe and in the favor of Allah they disbelieve?
And they worship besides Allah that which does not possess for them [the power of] provision from the heavens and the earth at all, and [in fact], they are unable.
So do not assert similarities to Allah. Indeed, Allah knows and you do not know.

Allah presents an example: a slave [who is] owned and unable to do a thing and he to whom We have provided from Us good provision, so he spends from it secretly and publicly. Can they be equal? Praise to Allah! But most of them do not know.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 8
Indeed, from among them is the ambiguous [al-mubham], and it is the expression shared between a meaning from a word or a letter. As for the word, it is like *al-shay'* [the thing], *al-qarīn* [the companion], *al-ummah* [the community], *al-rūḥ* [the spirit], and their equivalents. Allah, the Exalted, said: "Allah presents an example: a slave owned, unable to do a thing [shay']" (16:75). He intended by it the expenditure from what He has provided.

a.g: And Allah presents an example of two men, one of them dumb and unable to do a thing, while he is a burden to his guardian. Wherever he directs him, he brings no good. Is he equal to one who commands justice, while he is on a straight path?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 8
And among them is the ambiguous [al-mubham], which is the expression shared between meanings of a word or a letter. As for the word, such as *al-shay'* [the thing], *al-qarīn* [the companion], *al-ummah* [the community], *al-rūḥ* [the spirit], and their like. Allah the Exalted said: "Allah presents an example of a slave owned, unable to do a thing [shay']" (16:75). He intended by it expenditure from what He has provided. And His saying, Mighty and Majestic is He: "And Allah presents an example of two men: one of them dumb, unable to do a thing [shay']" (16:76). That is, commanding to justice and uprightness.

a.g: And to Allah belongs the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth. And the command for the Hour is not but as a glance of the eye or even nearer. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
And Allah has extracted you from the wombs of your mothers not knowing a thing, and He made for you hearing and vision and intellect that perhaps you would be grateful.
Do they not see the birds controlled in the atmosphere of the sky? None holds them up except Allah. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.

And Allah has made for you from your homes a place of rest and made for you from the hides of the animals tents which you find light on your day of travel and your day of encampment; and from their wool, fur and hair is furnishing and enjoyment for a time.

And Allah has made for you, from that which He has created, shadows and has made for you from the mountains, shelters and has made for you garments which protect you from the heat and garments which protect you from your [enemy in] battle. Thus does He complete His favor upon you that you might submit [to Him].
But if they turn away, [O Muhammad] - then only upon you is [responsibility for] clear notification.
They recognize the favor of Allah; then they deny it. And most of them are disbelievers.
And [mention] the Day when We will resurrect from every nation a witness. Then it will not be permitted to the disbelievers [to apologize or make excuses], nor will they be asked to appease [Allah].
And when those who wronged see the punishment, it will not be lightened for them, nor will they be reprieved.

And when those who associated others with Allah see their "partners," they will say," Our Lord, these are our partners [to You] whom we used to invoke besides You." But they will throw at them the statement, "Indeed, you are liars."
And they will impart to Allah that Day [their] submission, and lost from them is what they used to invent.
Those who disbelieved and averted [others] from the way of Allah - We will increase them in punishment over [their] punishment for what corruption they were causing.

And [mention] the Day when We will resurrect among every nation a witness over them from themselves. And We will bring you, [O Muhammad], as a witness over your nation. And We have sent down to you the Book as clarification for all things and as guidance and mercy and good tidings for the Muslims.
Indeed, Allah orders justice and good conduct and giving to relatives and forbids immorality and bad conduct and oppression. He admonishes you that perhaps you will be reminded.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 8
Indeed, Allah commands justice [al-'adl] and excellence [al-ihsan] and giving to relatives, and He forbids immorality [al-fahsha'] and wrong [al-munkar] and oppression [al-baghy]. And when his incisor was broken and he was wounded on the day of Uhud, and the blood began to flow upon his face while he was wiping the blood and saying, "How can a people succeed who have stained the face of their Prophet with blood while he calls them to their Lord?" — the hadith of his incisor being broken, peace and blessings be upon him, on the day of Uhud — the hadith regarding the revelation of "Not for you is the matter" — Muslim narrated it from the hadith of Anas, and Al-Bukhari mentioned it as a suspended comment — so Allah, the Exalted, revealed "Not for you is the matter" as an admonishment [ta'dib] to him for that. And the likes of these admonishments in the Qur'an are innumerable. And he, peace and blessings be upon him, is the first and primary intended recipient of the admonishment and refinement [tahdhib]; then from him, the light [nur] shines upon all of creation. For he was refined by the Qur'an, and he refined creation by it. And for that reason he, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "I was sent to perfect noble character [makarim al-akhlaq]" — the hadith "I was sent to perfect noble character" — Ahmad, Al-Hakim, and Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah. Al-Hakim said it is authentic according to the conditions of Muslim. It has preceded in the chapter on the manners of companionship. Then He encouraged creation in the beauties of character by what We presented in the Book of the Disciplining of the Soul [riyadat al-nafs] and the Refinement of Character [tahdhib al-akhlaq], so We shall not repeat it. Then when Allah, the Exalted, completed his creation, He praised him, saying, the Exalted, "And indeed, you are of a great character [khuluq 'azim]." So glory be to Him, how magnificent is His affair and how perfect is His favor! Then look at the vastness of His gentleness [lutf] and the greatness of His bounty [fadl] — how He gave, then He praised! For He is the One who adorned him with noble character [al-khuluq al-karim], then attributed that to him, saying, "And indeed, you are of a great character." Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, made clear to creation that Allah loves noble character [makarim al-akhlaq] and hates base character. The hadith: "Indeed, Allah loves lofty character and hates base character" — Al-Bayhaqi narrated it from the hadith of Sahl ibn Sa'd with a connected chain, and from the narration of Talhah ibn 'Ubayd ibn Kurayz as a mursal report.

a.g: And fulfill the covenant of Allah when you have taken it, [O believers], and do not break oaths after their confirmation while you have made Allah, over you, a witness. Indeed, Allah knows what you do.

And do not be like she who untwisted her spun thread after it was strong [by] taking your oaths as [means of] deceit between you because one community is more plentiful [in number or wealth] than another community. Allah only tries you thereby. And He will surely make clear to you on the Day of Resurrection that over which you used to differ.
And if Allah had willed, He could have made you [of] one religion, but He causes to stray whom He wills and guides whom He wills. And you will surely be questioned about what you used to do.

And do not take your oaths as [means of] deceit between you, lest a foot slip after it was [once] firm, and you would taste evil [in this world] for what [people] you diverted from the way of Allah, and you would have [in the Hereafter] a great punishment.
And do not exchange the covenant of Allah for a small price. Indeed, what is with Allah is best for you, if only you could know.
Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting. And We will surely give those who were patient their reward according to the best of what they used to do.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, whoever is patient [ṣabara] and seeks reward [iḥtasaba] attains the perfection of his reward. Then He recited His saying, the Most High: "What is with you is exhausted, and what is with Allah is enduring. And We will surely reward those who were patient [ṣabarū] with their reward."

a.g: Whoever does righteousness, whether male or female, while he is a believer - We will surely cause him to live a good life, and We will surely give them their reward [in the Hereafter] according to the best of what they used to do.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, in some interpretations [tafasir] of His, the Exalted's, saying: "Then We will surely grant him a good life [hayatan tayyiba]," it is said: "The righteous wife [al-zawjah al-saliha]."

a.g: So when you recite the Qur'an, [first] seek refuge in Allah from Satan, the expelled [from His mercy].
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, you know that these thoughts [khawatir] are occurrences [haditha]. Then, indeed, every occurrence [hadith] must have an originator [muhdith]. Whenever occurrences [hawadith] differ, that indicates a difference in their causes [asbab]. This is what is known from the established way [sunnah] of God, the Exalted, in arranging effects [musabbabat] upon causes [asbab]. So, whenever the walls of a house are illuminated by the light of a fire, and its ceiling is darkened and blackened by smoke, you know that the cause [sabab] of the blackness is other than the cause [sabab] of the illumination. Likewise, for the lights [anwar] of the heart [qalb] and its darkness [zulmah], there are two different causes [sababan]. So, the cause [sabab] of the thought [khātir] that calls to good is called an angel [malak], and the cause [sabab] of the thought [khātir] that calls to evil is called a devil [shaytan]. And the subtle facilitation [lutf] by which the heart [qalb] is prepared to accept the inspiration [ilham] of good is called divine enabling [tawfiq]. And that by which it is prepared to accept the whisperings [waswas] of the devil [shaytan] is called misguidance [ighwa'] and abandonment [khidhlan]. For different meanings require different names. And the angel [malak] is an expression for a creation [khalq] whom God, the Exalted, created—its affair [sha'n] is the outpouring of good, the bestowal of knowledge ['ilm], the unveiling of truth [haqq], the promise of good, and the command of righteousness [ma'ruf]. And He created it and subjugated it for that. And the devil [shaytan] is an expression for a creation [khalq] whose affair [sha'n] is the opposite of that—it is the promise of evil, the command of indecency [fahsha'], and the intimidation with poverty when one intends good. So, the whispering [waswasa] is in opposition to the inspiration [ilham], and the devil [shaytan] is in opposition to the angel [malak], and divine enabling [tawfiq] is in opposition to abandonment [khidhlan]. And to this, the indication is in His, the Exalted's, saying: "And of all things We created a pair." For all existents [mawjudat] are opposites, paired, except God, the Exalted, for He is singular [fard], having no opposite. Rather, He is the One True [al-Wāhid al-Haqq], the Creator of all pairs. So, the heart [qalb] is pulled between the devil [shaytan] and the angel [malak]. And He, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the heart [qalb]: "It has two promptings [lammatan]: a prompting [lamma] from the angel [malak]—a promise of good and a confirmation of truth [haqq]. So, whoever finds that, let him know that it is from God, glory be to Him, and let him praise God. And a prompting [lamma] from the enemy—a promise of evil, a denial of truth [haqq], and a prohibition from good. So, whoever finds that, let him seek refuge with God from the accursed devil [shaytan]." Then he recited His, the Exalted's, saying: "Satan threatens you with poverty and commands you to immorality..." [2:268]. And Al-Hasan said: "They are only two promptings [hamman] that roam in the heart [qalb]: a prompting [hamm] from God, the Exalted, and a prompting [hamm] from the enemy. So, may God have mercy on a servant who pauses at his prompting [hamm]; so what is from God, the Exalted, he acts upon, and what is from his enemy, he strives against." And due to the heart's [qalb] being pulled between these two dominions, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The heart [qalb] of the believer is between two fingers [isba'] from the fingers [asabi'] of the Most Merciful." So God is exalted above having a finger [isba'] composed of flesh, blood, and nerves, divided into fingertips. Rather, the spirit [ruh] of the finger [isba'] is the swiftness of turning over [taqlib] and the power to move and change. For you do not want your finger [isba'] for its person, but for its action in turning over [taqlib] and repetition. Just as you undertake actions with your fingers [asabi'], God, the Exalted, does what He does by subjugating the angel [malak] and the devil [shaytan]. And they are both subjugated by His power in turning over [taqlib] the hearts [qulub], just as your fingers [asabi'] are subjugated to you in turning over [taqlib] bodies, for example. And the heart [qalb], by its original primordial nature [fitrah], is sound [salih] for receiving the traces [athar] of the angel [malak] and for receiving the traces [athar] of the devil [shaytan] with an equal soundness [salah]—neither one outweighs the other. Rather, one of the two sides outweighs by following caprice [hawa] and plunging into desires [shahawat] or by turning away from them and opposing them. So, if a person follows the demands of anger [ghadab] and desire [shahwa], the domination [tasallut] of the devil [shaytan] becomes apparent through the medium of caprice [hawa], and the heart [qalb] becomes the nest and mine of the devil [shaytan], because caprice [hawa] is the pasture and grazing ground of the devil [shaytan]. And if he strives against the desires [shahawat] and does not let them dominate his self [nafs], and he resembles the character traits of the angels, peace be upon them, his heart [qalb] becomes the abode and descent place of the angels [mala'ika]. And since no heart [qalb] is free from desire [shahwa], anger [ghadab], greed [hirs], covetousness [tama'], long hope [tul al-amal], and other than that from the attributes of humanity branching from caprice [hawa], it is inevitable that no heart [qalb] is free from the devil [shaytan] having a roaming in it through whispering [waswasa]. And for that reason, He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There is not one of you except that he has a devil [shaytan]." They said: "And you, O Messenger of God?" He said: "And me, except that God aided me against him, so he submitted and does not command except with good." And this is only because the devil [shaytan] does not act except through the medium of desire [shahwa]. So, whoever God aids over his desire [shahwa] until it does not expand except where it should and to the limit it should, then his desire [shahwa] does not call to evil, so the devil [shaytan] armored with it does not command except with good. And whenever the remembrance [dhikr] of this world [dunya] overpowers the heart [qalb] according to the demands of caprice [hawa]...

a.g: Indeed, there is for him no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord.
His authority is only over those who take him as an ally and those who through him associate others with Allah.
And when We substitute a verse in place of a verse - and Allah is most knowing of what He sends down - they say, "You, [O Muhammad], are but an inventor [of lies]." But most of them do not know.
Say, [O Muhammad], "The Pure Spirit has brought it down from your Lord in truth to make firm those who believe and as guidance and good tidings to the Muslims."
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, I refer the guidance [irshad] to Gabriel [Jibril]. Thus, the Most High says: "Say: The Holy Spirit [Ruh al-Qudus] has brought it down from your Lord in truth."

a.g: And We certainly know that they say, "It is only a human being who teaches the Prophet." The tongue of the one they refer to is foreign, and this Qur'an is [in] a clear Arabic language.
Indeed, those who do not believe in the verses of Allah - Allah will not guide them, and for them is a painful punishment.
They only invent falsehood who do not believe in the verses of Allah, and it is those who are the liars.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book4a
Indeed, I was asked: "O Messenger of God, can a believer commit adultery [zina]?" I said: "That may be." He said: "O Prophet of God, can a believer lie [yakdhib]?" I said: "No." Then I followed it with the saying of God, the Most High: "Only those who do not believe in the signs [ayat] of God fabricate falsehood [al-kadhib]."
Vol3 book4a
Indeed, I was asked: "O Messenger of God, can a believer commit adultery [zina]?" I said: "That may be." He said: "O Prophet of God, can a believer lie [yakdhib]?" I said: "No." Then I followed it with the saying of God, the Most High: "Only those who do not believe in the signs [ayat] of God fabricate falsehood [al-kadhib]."

a.g: Whoever disbelieves in Allah after his belief... except for one who is forced [to renounce his religion] while his heart is secure in faith. But those who [willingly] open their breasts to disbelief, upon them is wrath from Allah, and for them is a great punishment;
That is because they preferred the worldly life over the Hereafter and that Allah does not guide the disbelieving people.
Those are the ones over whose hearts and hearing and vision Allah has sealed, and it is those who are the heedless.
Assuredly, it is they, in the Hereafter, who will be the losers.

Then, indeed your Lord, to those who emigrated after they had been compelled [to renounce their religion] and thereafter fought [for the cause of Allah] and were patient - indeed, your Lord, after that, is Forgiving and Merciful
On the Day when every soul will come disputing for itself, and every soul will be fully compensated for what it did, and they will not be wronged.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book5a
Indeed, Hisham was brought a man concerning whom a report had reached him. When he was made to stand before him, he began to speak his defense. Hisham said to him: "And you also speak?" The man said: "O Commander of the Faithful, Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has said: 'On the Day when every soul [nafs] will come disputing on behalf of itself...' (16:111). Shall we dispute with Allah, the Exalted, yet not speak before you with speech?" Hisham said: "Yes, woe to you, speak."

a.g: And Allah presents an example: a city which was safe and secure, its provision coming to it in abundance from every location, but it denied the favors of Allah. So Allah made it taste the envelopment of hunger and fear for what they had been doing.
And there had certainly come to them a Messenger from among themselves, but they denied him; so punishment overtook them while they were wrongdoers.
Then eat of what Allah has provided for you [which is] lawful and good. And be grateful for the favor of Allah, if it is [indeed] Him that you worship.

He has only forbidden to you dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah. But whoever is forced [by necessity], neither desiring [it] nor transgressing [its limit] - then indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
And do not say about what your tongues assert of untruth, "This is lawful and this is unlawful," to invent falsehood about Allah. Indeed, those who invent falsehood about Allah will not succeed.
[It is but] a brief enjoyment, and they will have a painful punishment.
And to those who are Jews We have prohibited that which We related to you before. And We did not wrong them [thereby], but they were wronging themselves.
Then, indeed your Lord, to those who have done wrong out of ignorance and then repent after that and correct themselves - indeed, your Lord, thereafter, is Forgiving and Merciful.
Indeed, Abraham was a [comprehensive] leader, devoutly obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth, and he was not of those who associate others with Allah.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 8
Indeed, the term 'Ummah' [Ummah] is applied in eight aspects... and it is a man who gathers goodness [khayr] within himself, so that others follow his example, as in His saying, the Most High: "Indeed, Abraham was a devoutly obedient [qanitan] community [Ummah] unto God."
Vol1 book 8

a.g: [He was] grateful for His favors. Allah chose him and guided him to a straight path.
And We gave him good in this world, and indeed, in the Hereafter he will be among the righteous.
Then We revealed to you, [O Muhammad], to follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of those who associate with Allah.
The sabbath was only appointed for those who differed over it. And indeed, your Lord will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection concerning that over which they used to differ.

Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction, and argue with them in a way that is best. Indeed, your Lord is most knowing of who has strayed from His way, and He is most knowing of who is [rightly] guided.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: "And argue with them in the best manner [wa jādilhum billatī hiya aḥsan]." The Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to debate the deniers and argue, but only when necessary, and the need for it was rare in their time. The first to establish the practice of calling the innovators [al-mubtadi'a] to the truth through argumentation was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when he sent Ibn 'Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, to the Khawarij. He spoke to them, saying, "What do you find fault with regarding your Imam?" They said, "He fought but did not take captives nor spoils." He said, "That was in fighting the disbelievers. Tell me, if 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her, were to be taken as a captive in the share of one of you, would you deem lawful for her what you deem lawful from your spoils, when she is your mother according to the clear text of the Book?" They said, "No." So, two thousand of them returned to obedience due to his argumentation. And it is narrated that Al-Hasan debated a Qadari and he retracted from Qadr (denying divine decree). And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, debated a man from the Qadariyya. And 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, debated Yazid ibn 'Umayra regarding faith [al-īmān]. 'Abdullah said, "If I said I am a believer [mu'min], I would be saying I am in Paradise." Yazid ibn 'Umayra said to him, "O companion of the Messenger of Allah, this is a slip from you. Is faith [al-īmān] not but that you believe in Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, the Resurrection, the Balance, and that you establish prayer, fasting, and zakah? And we have sins; if we knew they would be forgiven for us, we would know we are among the people of Paradise. It is for this reason we say we are believers [mu'minūn] and we do not say we are among the people of Paradise." Ibn Mas'ud said, "You have spoken the truth, by Allah. It was indeed a slip from me." Therefore, it should be said: Their delving into it was little, not much; and short, not long; and when necessary, not by way of authoring books and teaching, and making it a craft. So it is said: As for the littleness of their delving into it, it was due to the rarity of the need, as innovation [al-bid'a] was not manifest in that time. As for its brevity, the goal was only to silence the opponent, his admission, the unveiling of the truth [ḥaqq], and the removal of doubt. So if the opponent's confusion or obstinacy was prolonged, their refutation would inevitably be prolonged, and they would not measure the extent of the need with a scale or a measure after embarking upon it. As for their not undertaking to teach and author books on it, such was their way in jurisprudence [al-fiqh], exegesis [al-tafsīr], and hadith as well. For if authoring books on jurisprudence and positing rare scenarios that only occur infrequently is permissible—either in preparation for their occurrence, even if rare, or to sharpen the intellects—then [the same applies here].

a.g: And if you punish [an enemy, O believers], punish with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed. But if you are patient - it is better for those who are patient.
And be patient, [O Muhammad], and your patience is not but through Allah. And do not grieve over them and do not be in distress over what they conspire.
Indeed, Allah is with those who fear Him and those who are doers of good.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Know, O son of my brother, that this is in the Book of God, the Exalted, which was revealed: "Indeed, God is with those who are God-fearing [ittaqaw] and those who are virtuous doers of good [muhsinun]."
